trial_identification.studytitle: Comparison of dexamethasone route of administration on ankle block duration and analgesia for foot and ankle surgery
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Comparison of dexamethasone route of administration on ankle block duration and analgesia for foot and ankle surgery

interventions.interventions:
Patients undergoing elective ankle or foot surgery will receive an ultrasound guided ankle/foot block and be randomly allocated to one of three groups:
Arm 1 The intravenous dexamethasone group will receive 8 mg (2 ml) dexamethasone intravenously and 2 ml saline added to the ropivacaine ankle block.
Arm 2 The ankle block dexamethasone group will receive 8 mg (2 ml) dexamethasone added into the ropivacaine ankle block and 2 ml saline intravenously.
interventions.comparator: Arm 3 Receive no dexamethasone. The control group will receive 2 ml saline intravenously and 2 ml saline added to the ropivacaine ankle block.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Duration before analgesic effect of block wears off as reported by the patient
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Checked at day 1 post-operatively as reported by the patient using a visual analogue scale

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Pain score at surgical site when the block had worn off
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Checked at day 1 post-operatively as reported by the patient using a visual analogue scale

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Highest pain score as reported by the patient within 7 days
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Checked at day 7 post-operatively as reported by the patient using a visual analogue scale
In post-operative recovery and on Day 7 as reported by the patient using patient self-report questionnaire

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Use of analgesic medication during first 7 days post-operatively
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Checked at day 7 post-operatively as reported by the patient using a patient self-report questionnaire
Post anaesthetic care unit as reported by the patient using a visual analogue scale

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Adverse events related to having the ankle block including nerve damage. These adverse events will not be known beforehand and this is to screen for potential adverse reactions which are not expected to occur.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Checked at day 1, day 7 and at the surgical postoperative consultation using patient self-report questionnaire

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
Elective patients having metatarsal osteotomy for foot surgery
American Society of Anaesthesiologists score 1-3
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
American Society of Anaesthesiologists score of 4 or greater
Contraindication to ankle block (patient refusal, coagulopathy, sepsis, local infection, allergy to ropivacaine)
Contraindication to dexamethasone (eg. known hypersensitivity, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus)
Pre-existing sensory deficit around the site of surgical intervention (eg. peripheral neuropathy, stroke)
Systemic glucocorticoid treatment of >10mg prednisolone (or equivalent) for two weeks or more within three months of surgery
Chronic opioid use define as >30mg oral morphine per day or equivalent (Fentanyl patch 12mcg/hr; buprenorphine 20mcg/hr; oxycodone >20mg/day)
Contraindication to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (eg. known hypersensitivity, active peptic ulcer disease, renal impairment, pregnancy)
Previous enrolment in this study
Inability to understand english

trial_design.concealment:
Eligible patients will be provided with a patient information sheet at their preoperative visit. At the subsequent preoperative consultation, the surgeon will obtain verbal and written consent.
Subjects will be randomly allocated to a group using sealed opaque envelopes. A nurse who is not involved in the care of the enrolled subject will open the envelope and follow the instructions to draw up two syringes, one for the block and one for intravenous administration.
These syringes will be marked 'block' and 'intravenous' and given to the anaesthetist by another nurse.
trial_design.sequence: Permuted block randomisation using online computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Post operative pain following ankle and foot surgery is troublesome. It is common practice for regional anaesthetic blockade to be used to prolong post operative pain relief for about 14 hours. Dexamethasone has been shown to prolong regional blockade in the upper limb, but this has not been investigated in the lower limb. The optimal route of administration for dexamethasone has not been investigated and it is unknown whether there is advantage to administering dexamethasone intravenously, or mixed with the block. We aim to investigate whether dexamethasone can prolong regional anaesthesia in the lower limb and determine if there are differences in effect when administered intravenously compared with when it is added to the block.
